CZ_NAME_STR: UTAHS DIXIE AND ZION NATIONAL PARK (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A private debris burn turned into a wildfire near Toquerville, with flames consuming approximately 250 acres of grassland. Two firefighters suffered heat exhaustion while fighting the blaze; one was treated at the scene, while the other was taken to the hospital for observation.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A debris burn near Toquerville, Utah got out of control on May 1st, becoming a wildfire in rural Washington County.

CZ_NAME_STR: UTAHS DIXIE AND ZION NATIONAL PARK (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Quail Fire began near Leeds, Utah on June 23rd, and was ignited by people burning debris. The fire threatened some residences in the area, with approximately 60 homes being evacuated, and also threatened a desert tortoise habitat. Two sheds were destroyed in the fire, local power infrastructure was damaged, and one firefighter suffered a heat-related injury. The fire burned 1,708 acres before being 100% contained on June 25th, and fire suppression cost a total of $250,000. This fire is not to be confused with another Quail Fire that began in July near Alpine, Utah.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With very dry fuels, a very dry air mass, and an increasing southwesterly flow as a low pressure system remained near the Pacific Coast, conditions across Utah became perfect for explosive fire growth. The winds were severe at times across northwest Utah, and any fires that started spread very quickly. Several of these wildfires caused property damage or injuries, and one caused a fatality. Note that some of these fires continued into July.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The New Harmony Fire started on June 27th near New Harmony, Utah, due to a water pump malfunction on private land. The fire burned 1,957 acres before it was 100% contained on June 30th. 7 residences were destroyed, 22 non-residential buildings were destroyed, and numerous vehicles were heavily damaged. At least 60 power poles were damaged in the fire, and there was one injury, a firefighter who received first and second degree burns. In addition to physical damages, fire suppression costs totaled $421,000.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry conditions persisted across Utah through the end of June. This led to several more wildfire ignitions at the end of the month, some of which caused property damage or injuries. Note that most of these fires continued into July.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Shingle Fire began on July 1st, five miles east of Duck Creek, Utah and 4 miles south of State Route 14. The fire was caused by sparks from an ATV. In total, the Shingle Fire burned 8,061 acres before it was 100% contained on July 11th. Four firefighters were injured while fighting the blaze. The fire caused the evacuation of approximately 500 structures, and ultimately destroyed one residence and one non-residential building. In addition to these property damages, fire suppression costs totaled $7.1 million.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Many of the wildfires that began in late June continued into July, burning thousands of acres and causing millions of dollars in damage. Note that this episode began in June.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Baboon Fire began on July 12th, five miles southwest of Minersville, Utah, and was caused by lightning. The fire was originally thought to be 100% contained on July 16th, but began to spread again later in the month, when it was truly 100% contained on July 27th. This second flare-up caused no additional structural damage, and burned an additional 1,700 acres, bringing the total acreage consumed by the fire to 20,732 acres. This fire threatened the Circle Four Hog Farm, a very large farm with hundreds of thousands of pigs. Employees were evacuated from the farm for a short period of time, but the pigs were not evacuated. State Route 130 was also closed for about a day due to the fire. Two non-residential buildings were destroyed in the fire, one of them being a commercial building. In addition to these property damages, fire suppression costs totaled $650,000.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Baboon Fire began on July 12th in southwest Utah, and burned for about half of the month. The fire was named after nearby Baboon Peak. This fire caused evacuations and destroyed a couple of buildings before it became fully contained.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire began just north of Cedar City and was fueled by strong winds, before being contained after burning 45 acres. A landowner had been doing a controlled burn on April 24, and thought had put it out, but some of the embers reignited the blaze with the strong winds and got out of control on April 25. The fire threatened, but did not reach, 30 homes in the area. The wildfire consumed three power poles and caused a power outage; Rocky Mountain Power estimated the damage at $15,000.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving storm system passed through Utah beginning April 25. The primary threat from this storm was gusty winds in the southern half of the state.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Brianhead Fire started on June 17, when a man used a weed torch at his Brian Head area cabin, and the fire became out of control. The fire burned 71,675 acres, with most of the growth in the first two weeks of the fire. The Brianhead Fire destroyed 13 homes and 13 minor structures. A priority sage grouse habitat was also impacted east of the fire perimeter in the Panguitch watershed area. Costs associated with the fire were approximately $36.6 million, with rehabilitation efforts projected to cost double or triple that amount. At the height of the fire, approximately 1,831 personnel were fighting to contain the wildfire, and 1,562 people were evacuated from 11 communities in Iron and Garfield counties. The fire was contained on July 28. Note that this event continued into July.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Brianhead Fire in southern Utah began on June 17 and burned for over a month before becoming 100% contained. Note that this episode continued into July.
